summary: This is a civil complaint filed by the Government of the United States Virgin Islands against the Estate of Jeffrey E. Epstein and several corporate entities (The 1953 Trust, Plan D, LLC, Great St. Jim, LLC, Nautilus, Inc., Hyperion Air, LLC, Poplar, Inc.). The complaint alleges these entities formed an 'Epstein Enterprise' that engaged in a pattern of sex trafficking, sexual abuse, and forced labor of young women and underage girls at Epstein's properties on Little St. James and Great St. James islands. The government seeks damages and enforcement of Virgin Islands laws. This document is a section of a civil complaint filed by the Government of the Virgin Islands (GVI) against the Estate of Jeffrey E. Epstein. It details allegations that the 'Epstein Enterprise' engaged in human trafficking, forced labor, and sexual servitude in the Virgin Islands, violated environmental and construction laws, and used a network of corporate entities to conceal its activities. The complaint seeks civil penalties, damages, and forfeiture of properties used in the criminal enterprise. This document is a section of a civil complaint filed by the Government of the Virgin Islands (GVI) against the Estate of Jeffrey Epstein and other unnamed Defendants. It details multiple counts under the Criminally Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act (CICO), alleging the operation of a criminal enterprise involving human trafficking, forced labor, sexual servitude, child abuse, rape, and prostitution at Epstein's properties in the Virgin Islands. This is the final section of a civil complaint filed by the Government of the Virgin Islands (GVI) against the Estate of Jeffrey Epstein and other defendants. It details multiple counts under the Criminally Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act (CICO), including sex offender registry violations, fraudulent conveyance, and civil conspiracy. The document seeks extensive financial penalties, forfeiture of property, and dissolution of the 'Epstein Enterprise'.

persons.name: Jeffrey E. Epstein
persons.context: The central figure of the 'Epstein Enterprise,' accused posthumously of human trafficking, forced labor, sexual servitude, and financial fraud. The complaint details his failure to report travel as a registered sex offender and his alleged fraudulent transfer of assets before his death.

persons.name: Darren K. Indyke
persons.role: Executor of the Estate, Secretary of corporate entities
persons.context: Named as an Executor of Jeffrey Epstein's Estate and the secretary of corporate defendants Nautilus, Inc. and Poplar, Inc.

persons.name: Richard D. Kahn
persons.role: Executor of the Estate, Treasurer of corporate entities
persons.context: Named as an Executor of Jeffrey Epstein's Estate and the treasurer of corporate defendants Nautilus, Inc. and Poplar, Inc.

persons.name: Larry Visoski
persons.context: Identified as a member or co-member in companies (Freedom Air Petroleum, LLC and JEGE, LLC) that serviced and maintained the planes used by the Epstein Enterprise to traffic victims.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.role: Accused, Central Figure of the Enterprise
persons.context: Named as the central figure of the 'Epstein Enterprise,' which is accused of engaging in widespread human trafficking, sexual abuse of minors, and other crimes. The complaint alleges he and others engaged in sexual acts with underage girls at his properties.

connections.description: Indyke served as an executor of Epstein's estate and held officer positions (secretary) in Epstein's corporate entities.
Kahn served as an executor of Epstein's estate and held officer positions (treasurer) in Epstein's corporate entities.
Visoski was Epstein's pilot and was listed as the manager/member of corporate entities (Plan D, LLC, Hyperion Air, LLC) that owned aircraft used by Epstein.
Co-executors of Jeffrey Epstein's Estate and co-officers (secretary and treasurer) in his corporate entities Nautilus, Inc. and Poplar, Inc.

events.title: Acquisition of Little St. James
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein acquired the private island of Little St. James in the Virgin Islands, which the complaint alleges became a hideaway for trafficking and abusing victims.

events.title: Epstein Registers as Sex Offender in VI
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein registered as a Tier 1 sex offender in the Virgin Islands following his Florida conviction for procuring a minor for prostitution.

events.title: Acquisition of Great St. James
events.description: Epstein, through the entity Great St. Jim, LLC, purchased the island of Great St. James, allegedly to further shield his criminal activities on neighboring Little St. James.

events.title: Death of Jeffrey Epstein
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was found dead while in custody in New York for sex crimes.

events.title: Filing of Probate Petition
events.description: Executors Darren K. Indyke and Richard D. Kahn filed a Petition for Probate and Letters Testamentary for Epstein's estate in the Virgin Islands Superior Court.

events.title: Pattern of Trafficking and Abuse
events.description: The complaint alleges the 'Epstein Enterprise' engaged in a pattern of trafficking and sexually abusing young women and underage girls in the Virgin Islands over nearly two decades.

events.title: Epstein's Last Sex Offender Verification
events.description: Epstein refused to permit Virgin Islands Department of Justice Investigators and U.S. Marshals to enter Little St. James beyond its dock for a sex offender registration verification, claiming the dock was his 'front door.' He instead met them at his office on St. Thomas.

events.title: Epstein's Misleading Travel Notification
events.description: The Virgin Islands was notified that Epstein would travel to France for 10 days on a private plane. His notification form did not disclose travel to Vienna and Monaco, which law enforcement later discovered.

events.title: Estate Files Motion for Claims Resolution Program
events.description: Epstein's Estate filed an Expedited Motion for Establishment of a Voluntary Claims Resolution Program in the Superior Court of the Virgin Islands, which the GVI alleges aims to conceal criminal activities and shield participants from liability.

events.title: GVI Files Civil Complaint Against Epstein Estate
events.description: The Government of the Virgin Islands files a comprehensive civil lawsuit against the Estate of Jeffrey E. Epstein and other defendants, alleging violations of CICO including human trafficking, forced labor, sexual servitude, sex offender registry violations, and fraudulent conveyance.

events.title: Epstein's Unreported Travel to Vienna and Monaco
events.description: The complaint alleges that Epstein, a registered sex offender in the Virgin Islands, traveled to Vienna and Monaco on at least two occasions without disclosing the travel to the Virgin Islands sex offender registry as required by law.

events.title: Fraudulent Asset Transfer to The 1953 Trust
events.description: Allegedly, days before his death, Epstein transferred significant assets into 'The 1953 Trust' in an effort to defeat creditor claims and avoid court oversight of his estate probate.

locations: Little St. James, U.S. Virgin Islands
Great St. James, U.S. Virgin Islands
Little St. James (Epstein's property in the Virgin Islands)
keyFacts: The complaint alleges Jeffrey Epstein and a network of corporate entities (the 'Epstein Enterprise') engaged in sex trafficking, sexual assault, and forced labor of young women and underage girls at his private islands in the Virgin Islands from at least 2001 to 2019.

Epstein's estate in the Virgin Islands was valued at over $577 million, including $86 million for Little St. James and Great St. James, $56 million for a New York brownstone, and $72 million for a New Mexico ranch.

Corporate entities like Nautilus, Inc. (owner of Little St. James) and Plan D, LLC/Hyperion Air, LLC (owners of aircraft) are accused of being instrumentalities used to facilitate, conceal, and carry out Epstein's crimes.

The complaint describes specific victim accounts, including a 15-year-old who tried to escape Little St. James by swimming and was recaptured, and victims being lured with promises of modeling careers or massage jobs before being coerced into sexual acts.
Epstein purchased Great St. James in 2016, allegedly to create a buffer zone to prevent detection of activities on Little St. James and to hinder victims from escaping or seeking help.

The 'Epstein Enterprise' is accused of using the seclusion of Little St. James and Great St. James to traffic, harbor, and sexually abuse young women and children while concealing these crimes from law enforcement.

Epstein and his enterprise allegedly created a complex array of Virgin Islands corporate entities (e.g., Financial Informatics, Inc., Financial Trust Company, Inc.) starting in 2011-2012 to shelter assets, fund crimes, and conceal his identity.

The enterprise is accused of violating Virgin Islands environmental and construction laws, causing significant potential damage and incurring expenses for the government, and actively preventing routine inspections by the Department of Planning and Natural Resources (DPNR).

Employees of the enterprise were allegedly required to sign confidentiality agreements prohibiting them from speaking to law enforcement and were directed not to interact with guests or disclose events on the islands.
The complaint alleges that even after Epstein's death, the enterprise continues to exist and conspire to prevent detection and accountability for its criminal wrongdoing.
The complaint alleges the existence of the 'Epstein Enterprise,' an illicit organization whose primary purposes were human trafficking, forced labor, and sexual servitude.
It claims young women and underage girls were given scholarships, money, or gifts in exchange for engaging in sexual acts with Jeffrey Epstein and other unnamed Defendants.
The Defendants are accused of knowingly benefiting financially and otherwise from their participation in this criminal enterprise.
The alleged criminal activity took place at Epstein's property on Little St. James in the U.S. Virgin Islands.
The complaint brings multiple charges under the Virgin Islands' CICO statute, including human trafficking, child abuse, aggravated rape, and prostitution.
The complaint alleges Epstein violated the Virgin Islands sex offender registry laws by failing to report international travel to Vienna and Monaco.
It accuses Epstein of orchestrating a fraudulent conveyance of assets into 'The 1953 Trust' just days before his death to shield them from creditors and the probate court.

The Government seeks severe penalties including forfeiture of Epstein's Virgin Islands properties (Little St. James and Greater St. James), dissolution of the 'Epstein Enterprise,' treble damages, and punitive damages.
The legal action is framed under the Virgin Islands' Criminally Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act (CICO), treating Epstein's activities as an ongoing criminal enterprise.
The document is a formal civil complaint demanding a jury trial, filed by the Virgin Islands Department of Justice on January 15, 2020.
